answers.answer: They will probably check a 12 lead EKG and holter monitor to watch your heart rate/rhythm for 24 hours.  If this is not revealing, a 30 day event monitor may help.  If you have never had episodes like this before, it is possible that it won't happen again and might not be able to figure out what it is.Depending on the discussion you have with your doctor, a stress test is also reasonable.I hope this helps.

question: I'm a 48 year old male, insulin-resistant pre-diabetic with a strong family history of diabetes on my father's side, and heart disease and atherosclerosis on my mother's side.  My mother's mother died of sudden cardiac death in her early 60's, and her father of an abdominal aortic aneurysm in his early 60's.  I am generally sedentary and somewhat overweight (5'6", 165 lbs).  BP 120/70.  Resting HR 56.  I do not use caffeine, and I drink alcohol only occasionally.My father has diabetes and my mother had a triple bypass with aortic valve replacement (due to aortic stenosis) several years ago.  They're both in their late seventies and in otherwise good health.My brother and my first cousin (on my father's side), have chronic pericarditis, beginning at age 15, and my father has had several episodes of pericarditis in his 70's.Several weeks ago, while on vacation, I was resting in a swimming pool.  I suddenly started wrestling in the water with my son.  We were vigorously horsing around for about a minute.  I stopped because I was out of breath.  When I stopped my heart went crazy.  I had all sorts of palpitations.  It was very erratic, but it wasn't especially fast.  I was a little dizzy, too.  It lasted approximately 15-20 seconds, and then went back to normal (fast, because I had just been exerting myself, but normal rhythm).  This exact scenario repeated itself 2 more times within the next half hour or so.  It really scared me, so I just stopped playing around so hard.I've had mild palpitations before and since, off and on, but unrelated to exercise.  Lately I have been working on a project in my yard that requires a lot of exertion, but I build up to it.  I have not had any palpitations related to that work, although I have had to stop to catch my breath several times, with some very mild pain in the center of my chest.I'm going to see a cardiologist this week, but I wanted to know what he's probably going to look for.
title: Palpitations and sudden exertion
